1.text: Buy pre-cut firewood to play it safe, if possible.

2.text: Use manufactured fire logs for a purely decorative fire.

3.text: Find small, dry materials to use as tinder for a natural fire.

4.text: Find dry, medium-sized items to serve as kindling.

5.text: Collect a variety of fuel wood.

6.text: Build a fire on a clear, dry surface.

7.text: Build a cross fire structure to keep things simple.

8.text: Make a teepee structure for an easy-to-light option.

9.text: Set up a "log cabin" fire structure for easy building.

10.text: Use a lighter or matches, if you have them.

11.text: Spark a fire with flint and steel, as a weather-proof alternative.

12.text: Create a fire plough for a makeshift fire starter.

13.text: Start putting the fire out 20 minutes in advance.

14.text: Sprinkle water over the fire site.

15.text: Stir the embers with a stick or shovel while you sprinkle water.

16.text: Make sure that there is no steam, heat, or noise emerging from your fire site.
